# Installation

  • Installing Spark Via Composer
  • Authenticating Spark in Continuous Integration (CI) Environments

# Installing Spark Via Composer

License

Before installing Spark, you will need to purchase a Spark license (opens new window). You can purchase a Spark license via the Spark dashboard.

To get started installing Spark, add the Spark repository to your application's composer.json file:

"repositories": [
    {
        "type": "composer",
        "url": "https://spark.laravel.com"
    }
],

Next, you may add the laravel/spark-paddle or laravel/spark-stripe package to the list of required packages in your composer.json file:

"require": {
    "php": "^7.3.0",
    "laravel/framework": "^8.0",
    "laravel/spark-paddle": "^1.0"
},

After your composer.json file has been updated, run the composer update command in your console terminal:

composer update

When running composer update, you will be prompted to provide your login credentials for the Spark website. These credentials will authenticate your Composer session as having permission to download the Spark source code. To avoid manually typing these credentials, you may create a Composer auth.json file (opens new window) and use your API token (opens new window) in place of your password:

{
    "http-basic": {
        "spark.laravel.com": {
            "username": "taylor@example.com",
            "password": "your-api-token"
        }
    }
}

You may quickly create an auth.json file via your terminal using the following command. As mentioned previously, you may create an API token via the Spark dashboard (opens new window). This token may be used as a substitute for your password when creating a Composer auth.json file:

composer config http-basic.spark.laravel.com taylor@example.com your-api-token

The `auth.json` File

You should not commit your application's auth.json file into source control.

Once the package is installed via Composer, run the spark:install Artisan command:

php artisan spark:install

Finally, run the migrate Artisan command:

php artisan migrate

Stripe Billables

If you are using the Stripe edition of Spark and plan to bill a model other than the App\Models\User model, you should follow these instructions before running the migration command.

That's it! Next, you may navigate to your application's config/spark.php configuration file and begin configuring your Spark installation.

# Authenticating Spark in Continuous Integration (CI) Environments

It's not advised to store your auth.json file inside your project's version control repository. However, there may be times you wish to download Spark inside a CI environment like Chipper CI (opens new window). For instance, you may wish to run tests for any custom tools you create. To authenticate Spark in these situations, you can use Composer to set the configuration option inside your CI system's pipeline, injecting environment variables containing the credentials you use to login to the Spark dashboard and a valid Spark dashboard API token (opens new window):

composer config http-basic.spark.laravel.com ${SPARK_USERNAME} ${SPARK_API_TOKEN}
